content: Test cases should be equivalent to validators. Currently there is no visible test for the "words that start with uppercase letter" special case. I suspect there are other similar issues too with how many special rules this clash has.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Probably solvable in less then 5 minutes with Regex, but even without is not too much hard

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Les explications sont claire et le concept est innovant

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash, not too simple, not too complicated.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I was able to solve this in around 5 minutes, but it would be on the harder side for clashers who don't use RegEx, I would say.

I think Shortest mode should be fine, I'd guess I could shorten code in Ruby for this to about 200 characters or perhaps even down to 150 or so if I really made use of the 15 minutes. My ungolfed solution was ~307 chars, using full variable names.

I'm unsure about the shortest mode since I only got 290 chars in ruby. You probably could optimise my code but wouldn't get less than 250 chars. Everything else seems good. Although you may want to specify what the vowels are to remove since I've seen people say that 'y' is a vowel.

Goal
* Rule 2) Please format ",", ".", "?", ";", "'" and "!" as {{constants}}.

* Rule 3) Please format "a", "e", "i", "o", "u" as {{constants}}.

* Rule 4) Please format "Graham", "grhm" and "graham" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

* Rule 4) Please define "proper noun". For example, if [[message]] begins with a word which begins with an uppercase letter, how do I know if it is a proper noun or not?

* Rule 5) Please format "tone" as a [[variable]].

* Rule 5) Please format "lol", ":(", ":)", ":D" and "None" as {{constants}}.

* Rule 5) Please **exclude** ":" from the {{constant}} format.

Input
* Line 1: Please format "message" as a [[variable]].

Output
* Line 1: Please format "message" as a [[variable]].

Constraints
* Please format "message" as a [[variable]].

Thanks.

Done, but I'm not sure why to format the other "message"s as variables, since I'm just referring it to as a normal word and not as the variable name.
Also, my Clash is slightly modified, and I don't remember doing that. Am I hallucinating incredibly bad or can CodinGame moderators modify clashes?
(Oh sorry, forgot to save, 1 minute)

Yeah done, all changes are made üëç
Also, yeah it's pretty long for a shortest clash, took like 385 chars in mediocre python coding :/

Not really, I'm pretty sure I covered all testcases:
1) The fifth rule is spread across five testcases and validators.
2) The first and second rules are self-evidently the most used ones in all testcases.
3) Three testcases and four validators require the third rule to be followed.
4) One testcase (Under the weather) and three validators will fail if the fourth rule is not followed.
Fourth rule is really two different rules and only half of it is tested in visible tests. I know because I got 100% from tests and 60% from validators.
Oh, that is indeed correct; I removed the uppercase-checking condition and got 100% in testcases. I'll change it accordingly.

CodinGame moderators can modify clashes, but I didn't modify this one at all. (More accurately, it should be those players with editor rights, see here:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/approval-process )
Hmmm, it does seem some wording has changed since I commented‚Ä¶

Thank you for revising the contribution. Some points to be followed up:

*  Rule 5) Please format "tone" as a [[variable]] (twice).

* Rule 5) Please **exclude** ":" (the colons after each tone) from the {{constant}} format.

Constraints
* Please format "message" as a [[variable]].

Thanks again.

Changes are done üëç
So I should technically be able to modify clashes right? (Since I completed more than 300 clashes)

Thank you.

Yes, you should be able to. Just remember to follow some basic etiquette e.g. try to get the author's approval before modifications especially significant ones, leave a comment afterwards describing what you've modified, etc.
Yeah cool, thanks
You're welcome üôÇ
